body:
The ellipse pickle is the one you should be passing in the refine tracklets gui.

When I've gotten similar errors, it was because the number of tracks (number of animals) set in the gui doesn't match with the number of animals detected in the video, usually because of my user error (not setting it correctly) or because an animal wasn't detected well enough during the analyze video stage to be built into a track. For example, there are three animals in the video, so I set number of tracks to 3, but one of them is not well detected, so only two can be assembled from the detections. 

If you create a video with all detections, are all of your animals well tracked? If not, try setting number of tracks to the number that are well tracked, assemble new tracks, and try the refine tracklets gui again.

ok I thought it was the ellipse pickle (I am used to using the box pickle). 

This is an old single animal model that I created with maDLC2.2b8. I recall that the default number of animals in refine tracklets is set to 1so that should not be a problem. All the videos show great detections and tracking of my single fish. 

Should I change the config.yaml file settings from "multi" to "single"? This model worked flawlessly on 2.2b8 until I updated to 2.2rc1 and 2.2rc2.

Hey @kylecnewton, we found a bug yesterday where we realized it was impossible to reconstruct a single animal track from the GUI (#1298) as it was forced to a minimum of 2. I think that would explain your error. Could you try the following and let me know:
```python
from deeplabcut import stitch_tracklets

stitch_tracklets(config_path, 'path_to_your_box/ellipse_pickle')
```
PS: `conda install cudatoolkit=10.0` may fix the CUDA error but I'm not 100% sure about it 😄

> PS: `conda install cudatoolkit=10.0` may fix the CUDA error but I'm not 100% sure about it 😄

Do not pass lists, but strings only for your config and for the pickle file; e.g.: 
```python
from deeplabcut import stitch_tracklets

stitch_tracklets(r'C:\Users\Fish_Behavior\Desktop\DLCwork\1LZF_DLCma_model-Kyle-2020-07-29\config.yaml', r'C:\Users\Fish_Behavior\Desktop\DLCwork\1LZF_DLCma_model-Kyle-2020-07-29\videos\cropped_ALL_vids\20210526\New folder\20210526_AB_7dpf_0hr_CTL_0002downsampled_croppedDLC_resnet50_1LZF_DLCma_modelJul29shuffle1_100000_el.pickle')
```
I hope that helps! 😊

it worked! now I see an ellipse h5 file in the folder. What is the best way to proceed now? thanks so much for the help :)

100%|████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████| 1/1 [00:00<?, ?it/s]
<deeplabcut.refine_training_dataset.stitch.TrackletStitcher object at 0x000001CFFC011AC8>
>>>
Awesome! This h5 file is the final data file, from which you can create a labeled video (either programmatically or back in the GUI) and run your post-processing analyses.

sorry for not being more clear. Yes, I knew that but the problem is that I have 500 videos to finish analyzing and stitching tracklets. Is there a way to batch process this workflow? It seems like there should be, right?

Good point! 😅 This ultimate step of the pipeline is not batched as the number of tracks to reconstruct may vary from a video to another. In your case though, you could do something like this:
```python
from deeplabcut import stitch_tracklets
from deeplabcut.utils import grab_files_in_folder

config_path = 'your_config.yaml'
root_folder = 'path_to_the_folder_containing_your_ellipse_pickles'
for pickle_file in grab_files_in_folder(root_folder, ext='_el.pickle', relative=False):
   stitch_tracklets(config_path, pickle_file, n_tracks=1)
```

This pulls all the files ending in '_el.pickle' one at a time from a directory containing the video analyses and reconstructs the full animal tracks.

it totally works! thanks @jeylau 

one interesting hiccup: the batch process got interrupted by what seems like a corrupted el.pickle file. I went back and looked at the detection check video and there was an air bubble in the arena that was intermittently getting labeled as a body part. I am going to crop it out and re-analyze the video to see if that fixes the issue. If this were a case when I could not crop out the bubble, what would be the best course of action? If I could stitch the tracklet then refine it that would be helpful but I cannot even create the el.h5 file necessary to do that. What do you think?

Hey @kylecnewton, please consider closing this issue and opening another one that is more specific to the tracklet file causing you trouble. It's hard to troubleshoot otherwise, and will make it easier to reference it in the future. 😊
